newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Wesfarmers sees six pct EPS growth.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Wesfarmers sees six pct EPS growth.

text.p: Wesfarmers Ltd said on Tuesday that it expected earnings per share (eps) growth this financial year to be above six percent.
"We will get more than that this year," chief executive Michael Chaney told reporters after addressing the Securities Institute of Australia.
Chaney was referring to Wesfarmers' long-term goal of six percent real eps growth per year.

Earlier Chaney repeated forecasts made earlier this month that Wesfarmers expected a rebound in profits for the full 1996/97 year after a 27.4 percent drop in net profits to A$92.79 percent in the year to June 30, 1996.
He also said that full year growth would be less than the 65 percent profit growth recorded in the first quarter of the year.

Asked whether Wesfarmers agreed with analysts 1996/97 forecasts for a net profit before abnormals of about A$110 million to A$115 million, Chaney said he could not comment, except to say that: "We always, like all companies, endeavour to make sure that analysts aren't too far out."
Chaney said the profit growth in the current year was being driven by Wesfarmer's energy, fertilisers and chemicals divisions.
Chaney also said earlier Perth-based Wesfarmers saw similar real growth in earnings before interest and tax over the next four to five years as that experienced between 1991 and 1996.
He said Wesfarmers had achieved five percent real EPS growth between 1987 and 1996 and Wesfarmers aimed to achieve six percent real growth over rolling five year periods in the future.
